36492492.review:
Grapple is a hard game. The point of the game is iteration, doing the levels over and over until you understand what to do and until you get better at doing it. The camera is close to the actual "ball" that you're playing, which makes it difficult sometimes to see where you're supposed to go, and the game's visuals plays into this with its aesthetic and actual, invisible platforms in many levels. Don't expect to be able to do all levels in the first try; again, the game is about iteration and learning-through-doing. If you like games that will frustrate you a lot at times, then Grapple is a pretty damn good experience. If you don't, you will hate it and probably not finish it, because there is nothing else but the gameplay to get you through the game (meaning, there is no story).

As for my recommendation, I personally liked it, but I can see it being kind of a nieche experience. I would suggest getting this game if you like the core principle of grappling/swinging, because it does work very well in this game. I would suggest getting it if you like difficult games and overcoming them. I would suggest getting it if you like 3D platforming, and can oversee your perspective being limited while playing. If there is one of these three things that you find very unappealing, I would not recommend this game for you. It's that simple.

36228777.review: Very fun timekiller kind of game, figuring out how to finish levels was always fun whenever I was in need of something to do,  just two things though, I am now stuck on a mac and cannot play this game unfortunately, I don't expect it to be ported for mac just for me but it is a real good game and I'd hope they would expand to more platforms to get more people to know about it, or have access to it. And of course, replay value isn't really a thing with this game, atleast I don't think so, It's a breeze to swing through all the levels a second or third time, but, I guess that would be too much to ask from a puzzle game, once you figure out everything it's going to be easy no matter what, I can't blame anyone for that. That being said, it's still a fine game replaying it knowing what to do, but of course it doesn't have the same thrill the second time round. I'd wait a while before you replayed it, maybe like a year. Then come back and see if you can remember how to finish it. You might even have to put in as much effort as the first time. (maybe.)

33293601.review:
If you're a fan of platformers but are getting bored of those 2D sidescrollers, delightful staples of the genre though they may be, then Grapple will be a breath of fresh air.It is an extraordinarily unique take on platforming, with the grapple mechanic being as revolutionary to the genre as a portal gun was to that other, admittedly more-polished series.  Though this game lacks any kind of story element or graphical marvels, its simplistic yet unique aesthetic keeps the focus on the gameplay, which perfectly suits it.

Every level uses the same dozen-or-so assets in the same way van Gogh uses the same dozen or so colors in any one of his paintings.  That is to say, each level is a breathtaking mesterpiece of design that leverages a few basic elements to create 90 unique puzzles, often challenging you to come up with new and provocative ways to utilize the tools you're given.  Naturally, at least the first half of the game is relatively accessible and doesn't require too much thought or effort, but towards the end, especially the last ten levels or so, you'll run into some very rough challenges that require a fair bit more precision than the rest of the game.  With that said, it should still be completable even by someone who's a bit more casual.  Just don't ask me about the time trials, those are for a different breed of platformer enthusiast altogether.

And if all that sounds a bit too pretentious, the TL;DR is that it's a great platformer that's not overly difficult (unless you want it to be) and is unlike anything else presently on the market.

33117230.review:
Although the tag says that Grapple is a puzzle platformer, I would call it more of a momentum based platformer. The puzzle part of the game is more of gimicks and tricky level design. The game is very simple and there isn't much more to the game besides what the trailers show. There are currently 90 levels in the game and if you are good at these kinds of platformers you may spend as little as a couple hours completing all of the levels, however perfecting them may take longer. 

This game is nothing huge, the download is only a little more than 100 MBs and the game is cheap even when its not on sale. Grappler similar to games like A Story About My Uncle and Cloudburst with its overall structure. Mostly just platforming with new gimicks being introduced as you progress through the game. Graphically the game is pretty minimum with the same space overlay being used for every level in the game and platforms also using the same design throughout the game. 

The game worked perfectly fine for me, but that would have likely happened regardless because of my hefty PC build. Aside from that what is seen through the trailers is mostly what the game has to offer and Grappler is a decent little time waster if you don't know what to play at the moment and it kept me entertained enough to not put it down for a good hour or so.

40780564.review: Awesome addicting game. Is simply yet entertaining and satisfying to the eye at the same time, plus it doesn't matter if u have bad ping or no internet at all, its an offline game.

40419349.review:
If every game recently has become like Dark Souls, then Grapple has become like Spider-Man 2.

The good one, not the bad one.

Grapple is a game about a blob in space that you control through various obstacle courses to land into a blackhole about 90 times. Okay, so I'm not making the game sound that fascinating, but the gameplay is what's being focused on right now and after churning 16 hours into Pathologic, I needed a much-deserved "break" before I get back into the swing of things (no pun intended... I think). 

The controls and obstacles are what make this game really unique. Grapple slowly introduces concepts to you about momentum, different colored blocks, purple launchers, and smashing your keyboard to smithereens (although that part is optional)- and multiplies the difficulty of those concepts until you learn to simply get good at swinging around the obstacles. I get it. That's what a game is supposed to do. But after I beat Sonic Adventure 2, I sort of forgot how video games are supposed to work, so thank you for reminding me Grapple!

The game controls exceptionally well. It's a lot like the swinging mechanics of Spider-Man 2, with a much tighter experience than just swinging across an open world. It's tough- it'll kick your a**- but it's pretty fair throughout the experience. There were only a few times when I felt that something was either way too easy out of nowhere or something purely luck-based. There are even some levels where you can skip whole portions if you're clever enough (which I hardly ever am) and will certainly aid any speed-runners looking for something to get their rocks off to.

So... yeah.

Grapple is good.

7/10

Bye.

39811402.review:
I tried this a little in 2016.

Went and played Energy Hook. Got good.

And now I'm trying this in 2018. Now, swinging is a niche thing and I should warn you. This genre has a huge learning curve. You have to constantly understand everything. Your position in a 3d field. The distance between you and the next thing to hook onto. And your momentum/fight with gravity.

This game is frustratingly unforgiving. I say it's unforgiving because the hook has a very short distance and there is nothing but gravity that is going to give you your momentum. This means while you are in the air, you have a very tiny window to hook into the next ceiling. So much precision is needed here and it is frustrating to come up short.

This game is a lot like Super Meat Boy. Super precise timing is needed and the tool to instantly quit and retry is there, but there is no leaderboard. There are achievements.

You cannot skip missions and you unlock one mission at a time. This is a huge con.

Embrace the masochistic learning curve.

There are 90 levels.
